questions.question: Which of the following is true of graded dose- response curves?

answers.text: Graph of dose versus fraction of the population that responds at each dose against the log of the dose administered
Determines the minimum dose required to produce a specified response in each member of a population
Measures the therapeutic index of the drug
Determines the maximal effect an agonist can produce if the dose is taken to very high levels

questions.question: Which of the following describes the antagonism between histamine and epinephrine?

answers.text: Involves direct interaction between the drug and not through a receptor
Binds to a different receptor that has the capacity of producing an effect opposite to that produced by the drug it is antagonizing
Binds to the same receptor of the drug it is antagonizing
Competes with the agonist for the primary binding site

questions.question: Which of the following changes is observed when using an irreversible alpha receptor antagonist like phenoxybenzamine?

answers.text: Dose-response curve shifts to the right

questions.question: The following may result from beta adrenoceptor activation, except?

Which of the following is not true of fenoldopam?

answers.text: Acts via arteriolar vasodilation of both afferent and efferent arterioles
One potential side effect is hypokalemia
Has a long duration of action

questions.question: The following are true of captopril, except?

answers.text: Not given to patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis
Slows progression from micro to macroalbuminuria

questions.question: Which of the following  is true of nitrates?

answers.text: First-pass effect for nitroglycerin is about 90%
Nitrates cause methemoglobinemia at high blood concentrations
Adverse effects include tachycardia and throbbing headache from meningeal artery vasoconstriction

questions.question: Digitalis toxicity, especially arrhythmogenesis, is increased by:

answers.text: Has no effect on action potential
Also used for ventricular arrhythmias post-MI
Block ligand-gated sodium channels, hence its use as a local anesthetic

questions.question: Which of the following is not true of adenosine?

answers.text: Blocks AV node conduction by reducing calcium current
Has an extremely short duration of action
May cause dyspnea probably due to bronchoconstriction

questions.question: A 63-year-old man has a history of recurrent flank pain. Upon further probing, you discovered that he has recurrent calcium-containing renal stones. Which would be the most useful diuretic agent in the treatment of this condition?

answers.text: Causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis
Blocks bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubules
Useful for patients with edema accompanied by significant metabolic alkalosis

questions.question: Which drug acts as an antidiuretic hormone antagonist at both V1 and V2 receptors?
Which is an example of high intensity statin therapy?
Which statement best describes the mechanism of action of sitosterol?

answers.text: Cholesterol analog that decreases intestinal absorption of cholesterol
Niemann-Pick C1-Like 1 transporter inhibitor that decreases intestinal absorption of cholesterol
Binds bile acids preventing their reabsorption

questions.question: Which drug is classified as a 5-HT4 partial agonist that causes increased intestinal motility hence its use for irritable bowel syndrome with predominant constipation?
Which drug does not fall under the class of 1st generation H1 receptor antagonists?

answers.text: Works via phosphodiesterase inhibition and adenosine receptor antagonism
Pentoxifylline may be used for intermittent claudication
Clearance varies with age (lowest in young adolescents) and smoking status (lower in smokers)
May increase the strength of contraction of the diaphragm

questions.question: Which corticosteroid has the lowest systemic steroid toxicity?
Which drug selectively inhibits 5-lipoxygenase and is effective in preventing exercise-, aspirin-, and antigen- induced bronchospasm?
Which statement best describes the mechanism of action of bromhexine?

answers.text: Reduces disulfide bridges that bind glycoproteins to other proteins such as albumin
Decreases sensitivity of the medullary cough centers
Inhibits the afferent pathways that generate the cough reflex by modulating C-fiber activity

questions.question: Which drug is indicated for intractable cough from bronchial carcinoma?
Which is the most important excitatory transmitter in the CNS?
Which SSRI is considered teratogenic because of its association with cardiac septal defects?
Which serotonin antagonist is also an antagonist at presynaptic alpha 2 adrenoceptors and H1 receptors?

You, the ER physician, are considering serotonin syndrome. Which first generation antihistamine should be given to this patient to block the 5-HT2 receptor and to manage his condition?
Which dopamine pathway tonically inhibits prolactin release?
Which antipsychotic has the lowest risk of weight gain?
Which statement best describes the mechanism of action of lithium?

answers.text: Upregulates several enzymes involved in the recycling of neuronal membrane phosphoinositides

questions.question: Which drug should be avoided in patients taking lithium because they may result in an increase of lithium in the blood to toxic levels?
Which ergot alkaloid dopamine agonist has additional alpha 2 antagonist properties hence its use for intermittent claudication?
Which statement best describes the mechanism of action of tolcapone?

answers.text: Blocks L-dopa metabolism by inhibiting catechol-O-methyltransferase in both periphery and CNS
Blocks L-dopa metabolism by inhibiting catechol-O-methyltransferase in the periphery only
Enhances dopamine release in the striatum, blocks NMDA and glutamate receptors
Blocks muscarinic receptors leading to decreased excitation in cholinergic neurons in the striatum

questions.question: Which antiparkinsonian agent is associated with livedo reticularis?

Antidote for benzodiazepine toxicity

answers.text: Increase duration of chloride channel opening
Block glutamate transmission via voltage- gated calcium channels

questions.question: Reversal agent for zolpidem

This is the most common medical complication of chronic alcohol abuse.

answers.text: Also a weak carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and is considered the antiepileptic drug with the most anti seizure mechanism of actions
More likely to have SJS as an adverse effect in those with the HLA-B*1502 allele

questions.question: This novel antiepileptic drug is considered neither an inducer/inhibitor, hence the minimal drug interactions.

answers.text: Associated with megaloblastic anemia on prolonged exposure

questions.question: Which statement does not describe propofol?

answers.text: Induction agent of choice for unstable patients

questions.question: Su-ho, the Anesthesiology Intern on duty for tonight, was asked by Si-eun, the Anesthesiology Resident on duty about local anesthetics. Which statement made by Su-ho requires further teaching from Si-eun?

answers.text: Local anesthetics block voltage-dependent sodium channels and reduce the influx of sodium ions, thereby preventing depolarization of the membrane and blocking conduction of the action potential
Low concentrations of extracellular K+ may enhance local anesthetic activity
Local anesthetics diffuse within the membrane in their uncharged form

questions.question: Which local anesthetic has the shortest half-life?
Which statement about succinylcholine is false?

answers.text: Paralysis from persistent depolarization of the endplate
Cholinesterase inhibitors will worsen paralysis during phase II (desensitization) of the depolarizing blockade
Contraindicated in patients with butyrylcholinesterase deficiency

questions.question: Which amide local anesthetic can cause methemoglobinemia?
Which statement best describes baclofen?

answers.text: Alpha 2 agonist capable of increasing presynaptic inhibition of motor neurons
GABA-B agonist capable of facilitating spinal inhibition of motor neurons
Facilitates GABA-mediated inhibition via its interaction with GABA-A receptors

questions.question: Which opioid side effect has minimal or no tolerance, meaning they do not diminish despite continued use?

Which is not an agonist at the kappa receptor?

answers.text: Weak agonist at mu opioid receptor
Inhibits neuronal reuptake of  serotonin and norepinephrine
May precipitate serotonin syndrome when used with SSRIs

questions.question: Which statement made by Wonwoo, the intern on duty, about the treatment of acute iron intoxication requires further teaching by Mingyu, the resident on duty?

answers.text: Removal of unabsorbed tablets from the gut may be warranted
Correction of acid-base and electrolyte abnormalities is necessary
Activated charcoal does not bind iron in the gut and thus is ineffective

answers.text: A period of hypercoagulability with subsequent dermal vascular necrosis can occur early in therapy

answers.text: Weak acids that compete with uric acid for reabsorption
Given with penicillin to prolong effect by inhibiting their renal tubular excretion
Side effects include GI irritation, sulfa allergy

questions.question: Treatment strategies for acute gout include the following, except:

Which of the following is not anti-androgenic?

answers.text: Combination with misoprostol results in abortion of 95% of early pregnancies
Used in the treatment of Cushing syndrome
Physiologic antagonist of glucocorticoid and progesterone
The most common complication is failure to induce a complete abortion

questions.question: True of testosterone, except:

answers.text: Majority is produced by Leydig cells
Converted to estradiol in adipose tissues
The primary clinical use of the androgens is for replacement therapy in hypogonadism

questions.question: Which of the following is a short-acting low-potency glucocorticoid?

answers.text: Ceftriaxone is excreted mainly in the bile
Aztreonam has no activity against gram- positive bacteria or anaerobes
Ertapenem has activity against Acinetobacter species
Beta-lactamase inhibitors are most active against plasmid-encoded beta-lactamases such as those produced by gonococci, streptococci, E. coli, and H. influenzae

questions.question: Which of the following tetracyclines has the longest half-life?
Which statement does not describe protein synthesis inhibitors?

answers.text: Clarithromycin has a half-life of 6 hours
Streptogramins decrease the plasma levels of many drugs such as astemizole, cyclosporine, non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors, and warfarin
Clindamycin is recommended for prophylaxis of endocarditis in valvular disease patients who are allergic to penicillin

questions.question: Which of the following does not describe the mode of antibacterial action of aminoglycosides?

answers.text: The efficacy of aminoglycosides is directly related to time above minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) and is independent of concentration once the MIC has been reached
Aminoglycosides kill an increasing proportion of bacteria and at an increasingly rapid rate as the plasma level increases above the minimal inhibitory concentration
The killing action of aminoglycosides continues when the plasma levels have declined below measurable levels
Aminoglycosides have a greater efficacy when administered as a single large dose than when given as multiple smaller doses

questions.question: Which of the following is not a third-generation fluoroquinolone?

answers.text: Remains the drug of choice for most severe systemic infections caused by Aspergillus, Blastomyces, Candida albicans, Cryptococcus, Histoplasma, and Mucor
Liposomal formulations have more nephrotoxic effects

questions.question: Which of the following is not part of the regimen for testicular carcinoma?

answers.text: All are S-phase specific except cladribine
Long-term use of methotrexate has led to hepatotoxicity and to pulmonary infiltrates and fibrosis
The metabolism of 6-mercaptopurine can be enhanced by febuxostat
Cytarabine is the single most effective agent for induction of remission in AML

questions.question: Which of the following is not true of pathway- targeted anticancer therapies?

answers.text: Bevacizumab is contraindicated in patients with wet age-related macular degeneration
Gefitinib is a small molecule inhibitor of the EGFR’s tyrosine kinase domain
Toxicity of imatinib includes diarrhea, fluid retention, and congestive heart failure
Growth factor receptor inhibitors like trastuzumab may be indicated for gastric cancer

answers.text: Indigestible, hydrophilic colloids that absorb water, forming bulky emollient gel that distends colon and promotes peristalsis
Unknown, may directly stimulate enteric nervous system
Soluble, nonabsorbable compounds resulting in obligate increase in fecal fluid

answers.text: The patient may develop hypertensive crisis.
There will be no effect on the patient’s blood pressure.

Which of the following neurotransmitters in normally released by the sinoatrial node in response to blood pressure increase?

Takamura, 28-year-old male was admitted to the emergency department is vomiting blood. His supine blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg; sitting up, her BP is 50/0. Which of the following most accurately describes the probable autonomic response to the bleeding?

answers.text: Slow heart rate, dilated pupils, damp skin
Rapid heart rate, dilated pupils, damp skin
Slow heart rate, dry skin, increased bowel sounds
Rapid heart rate, dry skin, constricted pupils, increased bowel sounds

questions.question: Which of the following is the best drug for distinguishing between myasthenic crisis (insufficient therapy) and cholinergic crisis (excessive therapy)?

Mr. Muranishi, a 54-year-old man, had a cardiac transplant 6 months ago. His current blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg and heart rate is 100 bpm. Which of the following drugs would have the least effect on Mr. Muranishi’s heart rate?

A 40-year-old male was seen at the ER because of anaphylaxis and was immediately given epinephrine. Apparently, the patient has taken prazosin for his hypertension. Which of the following maybe observed in this patient?

answers.text: The patient may develop hypertensive crisis.
There will be no effect on the patient’s blood pressure.
The patient may develop severe difficulty of breathing due to bronchoconstriction.

questions.question: A 73-year-old man with a history of falling at home is found to have moderately severe hypertension. Which of the following drug groups is most likely to cause postural hypotension and thus an increased risk of falls?
Carvedilol is an effective antihypertensive agent that like propranolol, is capable of blocking beta receptors. An important difference between the two drugs is that carvedilol _________:

answers.text: Is a selective blocker of beta 1 receptors

questions.question: A 54-year-old farmer has a 5-yr history of frequent, recurrent, and very painful calcium-containing kidney stones. The patient has hypercalciuria caused by a primary defect in proximal tubule calcium reabsorption. Which of the following is the most appropriate chronic therapy for this man?
What is the major mechanism of action of gemfibrozil?

answers.text: ↑ secretion of VLDL by the liver

questions.question: Which of the following is a major toxicity associated with gemfibrozil?

After being counseled about lifestyle and dietary changes, the patient was started on atorvastatin. During his treatment with atorvastatin, it is important to routinely monitor serum concentrations of which of the following?
What is the reason behind picking up selective beta 1 blocker over non-selective betablockers for some patients?

answers.text: Selective beta 1 blockers cause less cardiac depression
Selective beta 1 blockers are less likely to bronchoconstriction
Selective beta 1 blockers are far effective as an anti -arrhythmia drug compared to non- selective beta blockers
Selective Beta 1 blockers are greater prophylaxis post-MI

questions.question: Freeza comes to the A and E department with numerous stab wounds after his battle with Trunks. The ER doctor administers pentazocine for the pain. Soon after administration the Freeza experiences sweating, restlessness, and an increase in pain sensations. What is the most likely explanation for his symptoms?

answers.text: Freeza is probably tolerant to pentazocine.
Pentazocine doesn’t cross the blood-brain barrier.

questions.question: Lorazepam can be safely given as a pre anesthetic medication prior to liver transplantation without the concern of excessive CNS sedation. What could be the best explanation for this?

answers.text: Lorazepam is excreted in unchanged form
Lorazepam is actively secreted into the GI tract

questions.question: Vegeta received a drug from Dr. Gero that binds to a subunit of the GABA- A receptor. When used at a high dose, the drug can open chloride channels independent of GABA. What drug was prescribed to Vegeta?

answers.text: What drug was prescribed to Vegeta?

questions.question: What is the mechanism of action of the hypnotic drug zolpidem?

answers.text: Antagonism of glycine receptors in the spinal cord
Blockade of the action of glutamic acid

questions.question: What is the antidote for benzodiazepine toxicity?
Which of the following best explains the phenomenon of rebound hypertension associated with clonidine withdrawal?

answers.text: Upregulation of α1-adrenergic receptors in peripheral blood vessels
Sudden decrease in sympathetic outflow leading to unopposed parasympathetic activity
Rapid increase in sympathetic activity due to decreased activation of central α2 receptors
Downregulation of β-adrenergic receptors, leading to decreased cardiac output

questions.question: Kyle, a 9-year-old boy, is sent for neurologic evaluation because of episodes of apparent confusion. Over the past year, the child has experienced episodes during which he develops a blank look on his face and fails to respond to questions. Moreover, it appears to take SEVERAL MINUTES before the boy recovers from the episodes. This boy is best managed with which of the following interventions?

Several drugs used in patients with advanced Parkinson’s disease allow patients to lower their dose of L-dopa/ carbidopa, and thus reduce the incidence of L-dopa-induced dyskinesias. These drugs also decrease the amount of “off” time for the patient. Which drug is used in this way but does not, if used alone, ameliorate the symptoms of early Parkinson’s disease or enhance CNS dopaminergic activity?
What is the rationale for combining levodopa with carbidopa?

answers.text: Carbidopa increases levodopa entry into CNS via inhibiting degrading enzyme for conversion of levodopa to dopamine

Carbidopa enhances peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine For questions 51 to 53: A homeless middle-aged male patient presents in the A and E department in a state of intoxication. You note that he is behaviorally disinhibited and rowdy. He tells you that he has recently consumed about a pint of a red-colored liquid that his friends were using to “get high.” He complains that his vision is blurred and that it is “like being in a snowstorm.” His breath smells a bit like formaldehyde. He is acidotic.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most likely cause of the intoxicated state of the patient?

After assessing and stabilizing the patient’s airway, respiration, and circulatory status, fomepizole was administered intravenously. Which of the following most accurately describes the therapeutic purpose of the fomepizole administration?

answers.text: Accelerate the rate of elimination of the toxic liquid consumed
To inhibit the metabolic production of the toxic metabolite

questions.question: The regular ingestion of moderate or heavy amount of alcohol predisposes to hepatic damage after overdose of acetaminophen because of chronic ethanol ingestion _______:
What medication will you prescribe to help a patient with alcohol-use disorder recover without adverse effects?

Master Roshi is a 60-year-old lad with a duodenal ulcer and laboratory evidence of Helicobacter pylori infection was treated with omeprazole, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin. Which of the following is the most accurate description of the mechanism of omeprazole’s therapeutic action?

answers.text: Formation of protective coating over the ulcer bed

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman with endometrial cancer came to an outpatient cancer treatment center for her first cycle of platinum-based chemotherapy. To prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, this patient is likely to be given which of the following?
Master Pogi, a 65-year-old male consulted your clinic for issues on erectile dysfunction. What medication can address his concern that warrants precaution?
Which of the following medications work to reduce both and preload and reduce cardiac remodeling in state of heart failure?

The patient is given an inhaled medication, albuterol, which provides immediate relief of the bronchial constrictive symptoms. The mechanism by which this drug takes effect is probably by which mechanism?

An 18-year-old female presents to the clinic with chief complaint of easy fatigability with associated pallor, tachycardia and murmur. Laboratory workup reveals low hemoglobin and microcytic red cell size. Which of the following is the most suitable therapy?

However, because of the high risk of recurrence of the DVT, she was treated with an anticoagulant for the remainder of her pregnancy. What will you best give to her?

A patient suffers from troublesome allergic rhinitis due to pollen, and you want to prescribe a drug for her that is least likely to cause sedation. What would your best choice be?
Which of the following compounds is most likely to block ADP receptors and prevent platelet aggregation?

A 55-year-old surgeon has developed symmetric early morning stiffness in her hands. She wishes to take a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug to relieve these symptoms. Which drug is an NSAID that is appropriate for chronic therapy of her arthritis?

A patient has been taking aspirin for rheumatoid arthritis for 8 yrs. Exacerbations are becoming worse, and she asks the physician about drugs that might stop the progression of the disease. Which of the following is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD)?

A 70-year-old man has severe urinary hesitancy associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia. He has tried an alpha blocker with little relief. His physician recommends a drug that blocks 5 alpha reductase in the prostate. Which of the following drugs did the physician most likely prescribe?

A 45-year-old woman was suspected of having Cushing’s syndrome. To confirm the diagnosis, the patient was given an oral medication late in the evening and had blood drawn the following morning for laboratory testing. The oral medication was which of the following?

answers.text: Can be made more easily by recombinant DNA technology
Has a higher affinity to thyroid hormone receptors

Which antimalarial drug can cause a dose- dependent toxic state that includes blurred vision, dizziness, flushed and sweaty skin, nausea, diarrhea, and tinnitus?
What is the mechanism of action of the most active drug used in the treatment of tuberculosis?

answers.text: Inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, thereby blocking production of RNA

questions.question: A female sexual worker from Amsterdam has a sexually transmitted infection and is for an outpatient treatment with an antibiotic.  She is warned that unpleasant reactions may occur if she consumes alcoholic beverages while taking this drug. The antibiotic can be identified as which of the following?
What is the primary mechanism of action of rosiglitazone in the treatment of type 2 diabetes?

answers.text: Inhibits SGLT2 in the kidneys, reducing glucose reabsorption
Stimulates insulin release from pancreatic β- cells
Inhibits DPP-4, prolonging the action of incretin hormones

questions.question: After numerous cycles of chemotherapy, a patient was found to have a high resting pulse rate. A non- invasive radionuclide scan revealed evidence of cardiomyopathy. The drug most likely responsible for this is:

A 54/M is scheduled for an elective colonoscopy that will take approximately 20 minutes. Which of the following drugs will most likely produce the desired anesthesia and anterograde amnesia?
How does phenobarbital exhibit its GABA-stimulating effect?

answers.text: By increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening
By antagonizing benzodiazepine sites on GABA-A receptors
By increasing the duration of chloride channel opening

questions.question: A 24/F whose husband recently died reports that although she is exhausted, it usually takes her 2 or more hours to fall asleep at night. Which of the following drugs would help relieve her sleep disturbance while being least disruptive to REM sleep?
Which antipsychotic is approved for schizophrenia in the youth and has been associated to galactorrhea?

A 5-year-old lad from Tondo was brought by her mother in your clinic. The child presents with pharyngitis and fever of 3 days’ duration. You ordered for blood works and microbiology reveals small, translucent, beta- hemolytic colonies sensitive in vitro to bacitracin. Significant past medical history includes a severe allergic reaction to amoxicillin when used for an ear infection. As a Topnotch baby you prefer to treat his infection but prefers not to use a drug that needs parenteral administration. Which one of the following agents is most likely you will give to be appropriate in terms of both effectiveness and safety?
Which of the following antibacterials are susceptible to bacterial beta-lactamases?
What is the mechanism of action of aminoglycosides?

answers.text: Causes misreading of the MRNA template

questions.question: The old drug Penicillin G is still considered as the drug of choice in the treatment of infections caused by which of the following bugs?

A 16/F cystic fibrosis patient is diagnosed with a ciprofloxacin-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa lower respiratory tract infection. Bacteria acquire quinolone resistance by which of the following mechanisms?

answers.text: Changes in the synthesis of DNA gyrase

questions.question: You want to treat Crayon Shin Shan 20-year-old male who has an ongoing UTI. Which antibiotic are you going to avoid considering he has G6PD deficiency?

answers.text: Ability to bypass the first-pass effect

questions.question: Bethanechol is primarily used to stimulate which of the following physiological responses through its action on muscarinic receptors?

answers.text: Contraction of the bladder detrusor muscle and increased GI motility
Pupil dilation and decreased sweat production

questions.question: Krillin, 6-year-old lad is admitted to the emergency department for treatment of a drug overdose. The nature of the drug is unknown, but it is observed that when the urine pH is alkaline, the renal clearance of the drug is much greater than when the urine pH is acidic. What can you say about the drug?

answers.text: The drug must be a strong acid
The drug must be a weak acid
The drug must be a weak base
The drug must be a strong base

questions.question: Miyata Ichiro is a 35-year-old male boxer had a history of IgA nephropathy. He recently underwent renal transplantation following years of steroids treatment and hemodialysis. He presented to the A and E department complaining of inability to walk properly. No other symptoms were reported. Physical examination shows inability to plantar flexion of the right foot and (+) muscular mass on the calf area. History revealed that he is recently taking a medication to treat an infection. 0 - 1.5 mg/kg as IV/IO

answers.text: 1 mg (1:10,000) IV/IO every 3-5 minutes For 21-22: A 25-year-old college student is brought to the ER for drug overdose. The patient was seen comatose with elevated respiratory rate and temperature. Serum analyses demonstrate that the patient has high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.question: 5 mg once daily
